Name: Common Juniper (Oldfield)
Notes: Common juniper is possibly the most widely distributed tree in the world. This circumboreal species occurs across North America, Europe, northern Asia and Japan. Common juniper is almost completely circumpolar within the exception of a gap in the Bering Sea region . It is widespread in North America beyond the northern limit of trees, occurring from western Alaska and British Columbia to Newfoundland, Greenland, and Iceland. Common juniper extends southward through New England to the Carolinas and westward through northeastern Illinois, Indiana, northern Ohio, Minnesota, and Nebraska to the western mountains of Washington, California, Arizona, and New Mexico. Common juniper is a native, evergreen shrub or columnar tree. Throughout most of North America, common juniper most often grows as a low, decumbent mat-forming shrub reaching up to 4.9 feet (1.5 m) in height and 7.6 to 13.1 feet (2-4 m) across. In parts of New England common juniper occasionally grows up to 25 feet (7.6 m) in height, and a treelike growth form is reportedly common in Europe. Height at maturity can range from 2 to 50 feet (0.6-15.3 m). At polar limits, common juniper grows as a dwarf shrub in forest tundra.

Name: Savin Juniper
Notes: Not frequently planted due to poor foliage and ragged nature. Grows on a variety of soils including limestone. Pepin Savin has greater resistance to blight than Savin Juniper. Any portion of the plant is considered toxic, if ingested. Easily grown in average, medium moisture, well-drained soils in full sun. Tolerant of a wide variety of soils including clay. Also grows well on limestone soils. Intolerant of wet soils. Tolerant of some drought once established. Also tolerant of many city air pollutants. The seed requires a period of cold stratification. The seed has a hard seedcoat and can be very slow to germinate, requiring a cold period followed by a warm period and then another cold spell, each of 2 - 3 months duration. Soaking the seed for 3 - 6 seconds in boiling water may speed up the germination process. The seed is best sown as soon as it is ripe in a cold frame. Some might germinate in the following spring, though most will take another year. Another possibility is to harvest the seed 'green' (when the embryo has fully formed but before the seedcoat has hardened). The seedlings can be potted up into individual pots when they are large enough to handle. Grow on in pots.

Notes: Kalm's St. John's Wort is a perennial, herbaceous, deciduous or evergreen shrub or small tree that, at maturity, can reach a height of 3 feet. Habitats include interdunal swales, borders of small sandy ponds, moist to wet sandy meadows, and moist sand flats (pannes).

The fruit size is variable, but most fruits are about 3.5 inch in diameter with a few seeds. Fruits usually occur in clusters somewhat resembling large purple grapes. Regular plantations of Karonda can be trained on single or double stem. Therefore additional unwanted shoots or laterals are removed from time-to-time to give the plant desired shape. L. camara has a wide environmental tolerance and occurs in a variety of habitats. These include wastelands, rainforest edges and beachfronts. It also grows well in disturbed areas such as roads, railways and areas recovering from fire or logging. In its native neo tropical habitat Flowering and fruiting take place throughout the year with a peak during the first two months of the rainy season. In addition to spread by seed, L. camara is able to produce adventitious shoots, especially shallow lateral roots, following mechanical damage. Hence, it is also able to spread and establish dense thickets by vegetative means. The capacity of the species to spread vegetatively and to inhibit both the growth of other vegetation and seed germination, in conjunction with heavy and regular fruiting, is the main reason why L. camara forms long-lasting permanent thickets. It occurs in lowland sites, treed or treeless bogs, peatlands, sedge fens and meadows, black spruce muskegs, and kettle pond edges.

Name: Curl-Leaf Mountain Mahogany
Notes: very white bark when young

Name: Chinese Mahonia
Notes: Also called Fortune's mahonia and holly grape. Native to China. Fruits only form in mild enough climates. Can freeze to the ground and regrow slowly the following year. Propagate with seeds, by separating suckers, or with cuttings. Lacks the stiff and sharp leaf spines of other Mahonias. Best in well-drained soils. Generally tolerant of poor soils.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Container Garden, Coppice, Dye, Food, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Japanese Mahonia
Notes: Native to China and Taiwan. Closely related to M. bealei (once believed to be the same species). Best in well-drained soils. Less tolerant of full sun in southern parts of its range. Spreads by suckering. Best fruit production occurs with multiple shrubs planted together. Flowering time varies significantly by region. Can grow in poor soils. Very tolerant of pruning.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Container Garden, Cut Flower, Food, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Leatherleaf Mahonia
Notes: Also called leatherleaf holly and Beale's barberry. Native to Western China, Japan, and Taiwan. May not flower in deep shade. Best in moist well-drained soils. Can be propagated by seeds and cuttings. Can be pruned into single-stem growth. Very closely related to M. japonica. Flowering and fruiting time varies by region.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Container Garden, Food, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Long Leaved Mallow
Notes: Silvery gray foliage. This plant is quite rare, and grows in the Sierra Nevada mountains, southern Spain. The foliage is unusual for a Lavatera and the leaves are oval, grey green, with a felt-like surface. The 2" flowers are not as large as the well-known cultivars, but very attractive being bright pink with deep red veining. In the wild they experience quite cold wet winters and coolish summers, so they may be successful even in Zone 8b regions.

Name: Parry Manzanita
Notes: A fire-resistant shrub often used as erosion control. Stems root where they touch the ground. Arctostaphylos parryana is a variable, evergreen shrub that can be prostrate, erect, or mound-forming. Propagation: Seed - best sown in a greenhouse as soon as it is ripe. Arctostaphylos seeds, especially if not sown fresh, are generally stimulated into germinating by one of two methods. The most effective is fire passing quickly over seeds that are lying dormant in the soil - this breaks down their surface coat allowing them to imbibe moisture when it next rains and then germinate. Alternatively, stomach acids act upon the seed coat when the fruit is eaten by various animals - the seed frequently passes through the gut unharmed and is deposited in a convenient pile of nutrients when the animal defecates - the seed will often still benefit from a period of winter cold before germinating in the spring. Both of these methods can be somewhat reproduced by the gardener - the seed can be placed under some straw which is then set alight - both seeds and ashes should be sown. Name: Bigberry Manzanita
Notes: Arctostaphylos glauca does well in heavier soils but also excels in decomposed granite. Needs water for the first year, then quite drought tolerant. Aka Eastwood Manzanita.

Name: Common Manzanita
Notes: Fire kills most common manzanita subspecies even at low severity. Roof's manzanita may only be top-killed. The roots of common manzanita are generally poorly developed, shallow, and vulnerable to heat, and its bark is thin and peels with age [62,66], offering little protection from fire.

Name: Downy Manzanita
Notes: A gray fuzzy leaf manzanita with smooth red bark. Woollyleaf manzanita grows in the pine forest of Cambria and throughout the pine forests up into the Bay area.

Name: Greenleaf Manzanita
Notes: Unlike greenleaf manzanita populations elsewhere, greenleaf manzanita in the Sierra Nevada and southwestern Oregon has a lignotuber . The lignotuber is described as a heavy, turnip- or globular-shaped organ that may form tabular platforms
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Erosion Control, Herbicide, Reclamator, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat

Name: Hairy Manzanita
Notes: hybridizes with bearberry (A. uva-ursi) to produce A. Xmedia Greene.It also hybridizes with pinemat manzanita (A. nevadensis). Fire best scarifies the seedcoat and results in greater rates of germination. Charred wood leachate may further stimulate germination of fire-scarified seed.

Name: Howard McMinn Manzanita
Notes: Ornamental cultivar introduced by the Saratoga Horticultural Foundation. Needs good drainage. Will accept more water than most manzanitas. Tolerant of poor soils.
Human Use/Crop: Container Garden, Food, Medicine, Ornamental, Wood

Name: Pine-Mat Manzanita
Notes: Pinemat manzanita roots adventitiously where stems contact soil.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Dye, Food, Medicine, Ornamental, Wood

Name: Pointleaf Manzanita
Notes: Defined as species that must have fires at regular intervals to maintain dominance. Between fires vegetative regeneration by layering occurs on the perimeters of parent shrubs and creates a discrete age and size "aggregate" from the center of the parent shrub to the outside of the aggregate. This assemblage may resemble one large individual shrub. As the parent shrub ages, it often senesces and dies while the aggregates continue growth leaving a "fairy ring" growth pattern
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Hedge, Insectory, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat

Name: Whiteleaf Manzanita
Notes: Has round gray leaves. New growth has red stems. Roots spread laterally. Fruit looks like tiny apples.
Ecological Function: Erosion Control, Insectory, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat
Human Use/Crop: Biomass, Dye, Food, Medicine, Medicine, Wood

Name: Maseyu
Notes: Velloziaceae (monocot order Pandanales) is the family with most desiccation-tolerant species (approximately 200 out of 270). More than 80% of the species occur in South America, where the greatest morphological diversity is also found. They are a dominant group of frequently co-occurring species inhabiting rocky outcrops of the Brazilian campos rupestres. Although until recently all tested Velloziaceae were described as desiccation-tolerant, recent studies provided evidence for a continuum of morphofunctional attributes, resulting in strategies to cope with drought that range from DT to non-desiccation tolerance. Velloziaceae form rosettes with a caudex surrounded by aerial roots that grow to reach the substrate. These aerial roots are covered by persistent leaf sheaths that help retain moisture and allow for direct shoot-water uptake.

Name: Australian Mint Bush (Native Oregano)
Notes: Native to Australia. Widespread and locally common, in habitats ranging from sheltered sites in closed or open sclerophyll forests and rainforest margins, to exposed rocky areas, often in elevated sites. Though Native Oregano will tolerate light frosts and full sun, it prefers temperate, partly shaded conditions. Choose a soil that drains easily, and water well in Summer. Enjoy the attractive dark green foliage of this evergreen shrub year round, with a bonus explosion of pink cup-shaped flowers through September and October. Like most prostantheras it prefers a well drained, moist position with some shelter from direct summer sun. Under dry conditions it will wilt noticeably but quickly recovers when watered. It is a good "indicator" of when watering is required in a garden generally. Propagation: Seed - sow spring in a greenhouse.The seed usually germinates within a few weeks. When they are large enough to handle, prick the seedlings out into individual pots and grow them on in the greenhouse for at least their first winter. Plant them out into their permanent positions in late spring or early summer, after the last expected frosts. The seed remains viable for 2 - 3 years in nor
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Aromatics/Fragrance, Container Garden, Essential Oil, Food, Medicine, Medicine, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Miracle Fruit (Agbayun)
Notes: Blooms and fruits throughout the year. Soil must be well-drained and high in nutrients. Needs humid conditions. A mature plant will flower and fruit year-round. Once the plant reaches two feet in height it will produce fruit. More fruit tends to set in the summer time. When the fruit is ripe, the berries turn red. Ripe berries will hold onto the bush for several weeks. Hand pollination ensures that fruit will be produced. Pollinate by shaking the leave back and forth or by rubbing your hands through the branches when the plant is in flower.

Name: Mistletoe
Notes: All mistletoes are parasites on their hosts, depending on them for all of their water and nutrients and varying amounts of photosynthetic products hence non mycorhizal. They do not grow in soil. Control of mistletoes usually consists of pruning the branches that are infected with mistletoe in order to ensure complete removal of the pest³-⁵. Branches must be pruned several feet inside (closer to the trunk) of the visible mistletoe plant, because any haustoria left behind can resprout. The mistletoe itself can also be cut off the branch, but most of the time it will grow back unless the remaining stub is wrapped tightly with black plastic or sprayed with pruning paint, either of which can kill the parasite.
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Insectory, Reclamator, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat

Name: Narrow-Leaved Mock Privet
Notes: An uncommon member of the Olive Family which is hardy in our area and makes a lovely evergreen alternative shrub or small tree. A small tree takes time and one English writer suggested it would be an act of kindness for future generations to plant one now. Small fragrant creamy flowers.

Name: Pink Morning Glory (Bush Morning Glory, Beshram)
Notes: Ipomoea carnea is a shrub growing 1 - 3 meters tall, with an erect or ascending habit when growing in open positions; in shady positions it is more likely to adopt a climbing habit with twining stems up to 5 meters long. After growing for some year, the stem becomes thick and converts into thick trunk and with several thick branches arising from the base. I. carnea subsp. fistulosa is able to grow in a wide range of habitat types, from aquatic to xerophytic conditions. It grows as a weed in disturbed sites, forest margins, open woodlands, grasslands, gardens and fences, and it also grows along waterways, in riparian areas, irrigation channels, swamps and wetlands. It can sometimes grow on beaches. The species can also grow in waterlogged sites, such as swamps and wetlands, up to 2 m deep in the water.
Ecological Function: Hedge, Insectory, Soil Builder, Toxin Absorber

Name: Prickly Moses(Star Acacia)
Notes: Grows well in heavy or sandy soils but does best in damp situations. Prune following flowering to keep bushy.

Name: Mountain Misery (Bearmat)
Notes: Forms dense stands (carpets) in conifer forests, Mediterranean climates. Resin is very flammable but the plant is often the first in after a burn. Resin sticks to clothing, hence the common name. Individual rhizomes can extend to a length of 82 feet and the roots can penetrate as deep as 4.9 feet. Aka Sierran Mountain Misery, and bearmat. The primary method of reproduction is vegetative. Mountain misery produces clones from its rhizomes, roots, and root crown.
Ecological Function: Erosion Control, Erosion Control, Groundcover, Nitrogen Fixer, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat

Name: Myrtle
Notes: No serious insect or disease problems. Root rot may occur in poorly drained soils. Watch for scale, thrips and spider mites. : Locate plants in full sun to light shade; heat, drought, and salt tolerant; avoid exposure to winds to reduce winter injury; plants are intolerant of poorly drained soils and high humidity, so they are often planted in raised beds or containers; growth is moderate to fairly slow, particularly on the compact cultivars. Propagated by cuttings.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Cleanser/Scourer, Container Garden, Dye, Food, Food, Medicine, Ornamental, Wood

Name: Southern Wax Myrtle
Notes: blooms and fruits year round.Is dioecious in flowering. Does not tolerate long term immersion of roots in salt water.
Ecological Function: Insectory, Nitrogen Fixer, Reclamator, Wildlife Food

Name: Painted Nettle, (Coleus, Painted Leaf Plant)
Notes: Plectranthus scutellarioides is an aromatic, evergreen perennial plant with erect to ascending stems that can become more or less woody near the base; it can grow 50 - 150cm tall. It does not form root tubers. The plant is sometimes harvested from the wild for local use as a food and medicine. It is often grown as an ornamental in gardens and as a pot plant in cooler climates; there is a wide range of cultivated forms, valued especially for their wide range of variegated leaves. Flowers are small, blue-violet, in slender, terminal clusters, and irregularly shaped. Blue-white two lipped nettle-like flowers appear in racemes, early summer to fall but are not showy and can distract from the leaves. The flowers are insignificant. The calyx of the flower is persistent and resembles a saucer hence the Latin name "scutella." Stems can be semi-succulent and light green, making them stand out from the leaves. This plant has 4-angled stems. This plant is grown for its multi-colored foliage. Too much sun will cause plants to wilt, too much shade causes them to become leggy. It is easily grown from stem cuttings in potting soil or a glass of water. Tolerates, or benefits from, cultivation...
Human Use/Crop: Container Garden, Dye, Food, Medicine, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Night Blooming Jessamine
Notes: Blooms periodically in warm weather. Returns from freezing to the ground in zones 8 and 9. Best flowering in full sun. Best in well-draining soils.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Container Garden, Essential Oil, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Norfolk Island pine (Star Pine, Triangle Tree)
Notes: Endemic distribution occurs in Norfolk Island (in the Pacific Ocean, off Australia's east coast between New Zealand and New Caledonia). It occurs as a cultivated plant in many subtropical and Mediterranean climates. In the U.S. it has been introduced in Florida and coastal southern California. Best in well-draining soils. Week root system- may require staking. Can re-sprout after damage. Roots may cause surface interference. Needles fall in too much shade. Even in Florida, these trees are subject to frost damage and produce multiple stems with weakly attached trunks - in the 2004 hurricane season, many of these trees failed under the 160 km/h winds. As a result some coastal communities (e.g. Vero Beach) prohibit their use as a tree in local landscape plan approvals because of the danger posed by falling trunks. Many of the "Norfolk Island pines" growing in Hawaii, including their descendants growing as potted ornamentals on the U.S. mainland, are actually Cook pines, the two species having been confused when introduced.
Ecological Function: Air Cleaner, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Food, Windbreak

Name: Boz-Pirnal Oak
Notes: Natural range is in Turkey, Asia Minor.

Name: California Coastal Sage Scrub Oak
Notes: With age, the root crown develops into a burl. Burls can become very large and dense after repeated top-kill.
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Erosion Control, Water Purifier, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat

Name: Kermes Oak
Notes: Quercus coccifera, commonly known as Kermes Oak or Chaparro, is native to the Mediterranean region and the North Africa Maghreb. In its native habit it grows in extreme Mediterranean climates and can be found on windy sea cliffs. It lives in areas with moisture produced by condensation fogs, many Ground frost on clear nights and sporadic snowfalls. A large part of kermes oak shrublands represent a degraded stage of former high forests of warm-region pines and oaks.
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Hedge, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat, Wildlife Habitat

Name: Mexican Blue Oak
Notes: Dryland plant of Evergreen Madrean Forest of SW North America.
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat
Human Use/Crop: Biomass, Container Garden, Coppice, Food, Food

Name: Sandpaper Oak
Notes: AKA Q. undulata var. pungens, pungent oak. Hybridizes with Q. grisea. Found in Chihuahan Desert and south Texas.

Name: Bush Palmetto
Notes: Grows abundantly in wet woodlands around Houston and Beaumont, also occurs in moist limestone soil along creeks in Central Texas. Needs plenty of water to establish. Specimen or background plants or in patio gardens. One advantage S. minor has over some of the other palms that may be considered for planting is its ability to grow a deep subterranean trunk (up to 5 feet deep) that keeps many of its vital parts below the frost line in winter and helps it to endure long hot periods of drought in summer. As a result, large, established S. minors can be difficult to remove permanently. Keep this in mind when planting this palm. This is a tillering palm, it exhibits saxophone style root growth (it has a heel), keep top third of heel above soil elevation!
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Groundcover, Insectory, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Habitat

Name: Panax (Geranium-leaf Aralia)
Notes: Panax can be easily propagated by cuttings. Cuttings should be 1 inch in diameter and at least 18” long ensure a successful planting. Panax can be started in the shade-house, but it also does very well by direct planting. If planting for a windbreak, plant at least 2 feet spacing for single rows. Stems can become woody with age.

Name: Papaya
Notes: Likes soils rich in organic matter that have good drainage. Fruits and flowers throughout the year. Commonly and erroneously referred to as a "tree", the plant is properly a large herb growing at the rate of 6 to 10 ft (1.8-3 m) the first year and reaching 20 or even 30 ft (6-9 m) in height, with a hollow green or deep-purple stem becoming 12 to 16 in (30-40 cm) or more thick at the base and roughened by leaf scars. Papayas are generally grown from seed. Germination may take 3 to 5 weeks. It is expedited to 2 to 3 weeks and percentage of germination increased by washing off the aril.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Food, Medicine, Oil, Wax, Resin or Polish, Ornamental

Name: Ichang Papeda (Ichang Lime)
Notes: This plant, which grows in a wild state in central and southwestern China, is doubtless the most cold-resistant of all the evergreen species in the orange subfamily. It differs greatly from the other species in the subgenus Papeda in having large flowers, and large, very thick seeds. The leaves also differ in having extremely long but rather narrow winged petioles, often exceeding in area the slender, pointed, lanceolate leaf blades. Citrus cavaleriei has long been cultivated in China, especially as a stock for more edible cultivars. An important factor in the hardiness of this species is the ripening of its wood, which is helped by hot summers. When ripening is successful it can survive temperatures below –18 ºC, but around –10 ºC may be about its limit in areas with cooler summers. The Ichang papeda's main claim to fame is its unusual hardiness. With the exception of the Trifoliate orange Citrus trifoliata it is the hardiest citrus plant, tolerating both moderate frost and damp conditions. For this reason, it is perhaps the only species of true citrus which can be reliably grown outside in the temperate areas of Europe and the United States. This is the hardiest member of the Cit

Name: Parrotweed
Notes: Thrives in well-drained soils. Tolerates a wide range of abiotic conditions. Wind and insect pollinated. Flowers sporadically throughout the year in its native range.

Name: Philodendron, Lacy Tree
Notes: Best in fertile, well-draining soils. Flowers periodically throughout the year. Stems produce aerial roots

Name: Albyn Prostrata Pine
Notes: Prostrate, creeping form of Scotch pine that forms a large, low, spreading mat. Glossy blue-green needles.
Ecological Function: Erosion Control, Groundcover, Reclamator, Wildlife Food
Human Use/Crop: Dye, Essential Oil, Fiber, Food, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Beuvronensis Pine
Notes: Very hardy, very slow-growing (1-2' tall in 25 years), dwarf evergreen with blue-green needles. ORIGIN: Witch's Broom.
Ecological Function: Hedge, Insectory, Reclamator, Wildlife Food, Windbreak

Name: Broom Pine
Notes: A dwarf witch's broom selection of Jack Pine with an irregular habit and dense growth to the ground. This cultivar originated as a witch's broom found in 1980 by Eddie Rezek of Malverne, Long Island, New York. Pinus banksiana 'Broom' is a dwarf selection of Jack pine that grows in an irregularly upright manner with dense foliage growing to ground level. The branch structure is irregular and curving and has short, shiny, medium green needles. It is extremely hardy and adaptable, to heat, cold, and dry, sandy or poor soils. After 10 years of growth, a mature specimen will measure 30 inches (75 cm) tall and 24 inches (60 cm) wide, a growth rate of 2 to 3 inches (5 - 7.5 cm) per year.
Ecological Function: Erosion Control, Reclamator, Reclamator, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Food

Name: Dwarf Mugho Pine
Notes: Dwarf plant that is bright green in all seasons. Mounded shape that can be maintained by pruning. Very hardy and rugged. Scale insects can become serious pests.

Name: Hillside Creeper Pine
Notes: Ground-hugging evergreen with green foliage turning lighter green in winter. Tolerates urban conditions. 'Hillside Creeper' is a fast-growing (12"+ per year), prostrate, spreading cultivar. Over the first 8-10 years, it typically grows 2' tall but spreads to 8' wide. Growth rate slows considerably as plant ages. Light green, twisted needles in bundles of 2 turn an attractive yellowish green in winter.
Human Use/Crop: Dye, Essential Oil, Fiber, Food, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Morel Pine
Notes: Somewhat resembles the shape of a morel mushroom. Dwarf form of Red Pine that maintains a dense, rounded, billowy form. Dark green needles. Intolerant of urban pollution, not recommended for urban plantings.
Human Use/Crop: Dye, Food, Medicine, Oil, Wax, Resin or Polish, Ornamental

Name: Dwarf Scots Pine
Notes: Compact, mounded Scotch pine with blue-green needles.
Human Use/Crop: Dye, Essential Oil, Fiber, Food, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Slim Jim Scots Pine (Scotch)
Notes: Dense columnar form of Scotch pine with twisted dark needles. Good for rock gardens and small lots. Shaggy orange bark adds winter interest.
Human Use/Crop: Dye, Essential Oil, Fiber, Food, Medicine, Ornamental

Name: Uncle Fogy Jack Pine
Notes: Weeping form of jack Pine with wild undulating branches. Name comes from the spring bud tips which "drool" resin. First discovered in a garden in Minnesota. Pinus banksiana 'Uncle Fogy' is a pendulous form of Jack pine with wildly undulating, pendulous branches. The winter buds are densely covered with resin. According to Iseli nursery, it is a "bizarrely attractive collector's plant." Typical rate of growth for this cultivar is 12 to 18 inches (30 - 45 cm) per year, obviously producing a very large specimen in very short order. It tends to grow upward for only a few feet (1 m) before knuckling over and hugging the ground. However, 'Uncle Fogy' is very forgiving of staking and aggressive pruning which helps to contain it and can allow for very artistic presentation. This cultivar originated as a wild-collected seedling found in the 1960s by A.G. Johnson and later planted in the home garden of Mrs. Wylder of Richfield, Minnesota.
Ecological Function: Erosion Control, Reclamator, Reclamator, Wildlife Food, Wildlife Food

Name: Blue Shag White Pine
Notes: Best in full sun. Tolerates a wide range of soils, but prefers those that are rich and well-drained. Intolerant of air pollution. Does not produce cones in early years.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Dye, Food, Medicine, Oil, Wax, Resin or Polish, Ornamental

Name: Pineapple
Notes: Best in well-drained, medium rich soils. Fruit is often less sweet at higher altitudes. Production continuous in the tropics, mostly during summer in sub-tropics. The plant requires 11 - 36 months from planting until the first crop of fruit. When grown commercially, the plant has an economic life of just 2 - 3 years, though the plant may continue to live and fruit for over 50 years. Individual plants are self-sterile, but sexual fertilization is unnecessary because fruit is produced parthenocarpically. Propagation: Seed - cultivars do not breed true and so seed production is usually restricted to the search for new cultivars. Crowns (leafy clumps atop mature fruits). Remove the leafy crown by twisting or cutting, remove any remaining yellow fruit attached to the crown then dry it for one or two days. Place the crown in a moist potting soil mix or in water until roots appear. Stem cuttings made after fruiting. Remove the leaves from the stems, and cut into pieces or lay intact in trays, covering with 2cm of rooting medium. Give bottom heat at around 20 - 27°c until roots are formed. Lateral shoots.Pineapple is a xerophytic plant. Its photosynthetic pathway is the Crassulacean Aci

Name: Pineapple Guava
Notes: Responds well to pruning, excessive pruning may reduce fruit set. Best in well-drained soils. Seedlings may not produce high quality fruit. Some cultivars self-pollinate, others require cross-pollination. Not always true to type by seed.
Ecological Function: Erosion Control, Hedge, Insectory, Wildlife Food, Windbreak

Name: Blue Plumbago (Cape Plumbago)
Notes: Can be grown in pots/containers which must be overwintered indoors. May be grown as a rounded shrub or trained with ties on a trellis as a vine. Site in locations protected from strong winds. During the growing season, it does best in consistently moist soils, but established plants are quite tolerant of some drought. When overwintering as a houseplant, bring indoors before first fall frost to a bright sunny room. Cut back stems hard in late winter to encourage new growth for the coming season. When overwintering as a dormant plant, cut stems back and store in a cool, dry, dark corner of a basement or frost-free garage. May be easily grown from seed, but plants generally will not flower until the second year. Plumbago auriculata is easily propagated from seed, cuttings and suckers. Sow seed in spring in seedling trays. Use good seedling mix and cover the seeds lightly. Do not allow to dry out. The easiest method of propagation is to remove rooted suckers from the mother plant. Plumbago auriculata will flower profusely after being cut back or after a growth flush, as it bears flowers on new wood. It may need to be cut back after winter to keep it tidy, even if this is only done ever
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Erosion Control, Groundcover, Hedge, Insectory

Name: P.J.M. Rhododendron
Notes: Slit any rootbound plants before installing to ensure water uptake. Frequent chlorosis occurs from high PH soils; best in soils that are rich, humusy, and acidic. Good drainage is essential. Flowers heavily each year but does not set seed. Blooms best if protected from winter winds and may scorch in full sun. More cold tolerant than the parent species.

Name: 'Decumbens' Rock Rose
Notes: This is a hybrid between C ladanifer and C inflatus so has no natural range but is a garden plant.

Name: Montpellier Rock Rose
Notes: Blooms in the spring with one inch soft yellow flowers that have a pleasing rose-like fragrance. As a species it requires a specific fire regime for regeneration, The moisture content of this plant has also been used as a model to predict the fire risk in Spain, therefore has a large influence on the fire regime. The Cistaceae family form mycorrhiza with ectomycorrhizal mushrooms (ECM), which produce fleshy-bodied mushrooms. Rockrose shrubs are thus a wonderful place for mycologists to find unique mushroom species such as Lactarius cistophilum , Lactarius tesquorum , Hebeloma cistophilum , various Russula and Hygrophorus , etc.
Ecological Function: Insectory, Insectory, Toxin Absorber, Toxin Absorber

Name: Hoary Rock-Rose
Notes: Labdanum gum is secreted from glandular hairs on the leaves and young stems, especially under hot sunshine. It was gathered by allowing goats to graze on and among the plants; the ladanum adhered to their beards, which were then cut off. Tournefort (1656-1708), a French Botanist, has given a detailed description of the mode of obtaining ladanum. He relates that it is now gathered by means of a Aasavronjpmv or kind of flail with which the plants are threshed. When these thongs are loaded with the fiagrant and sticky resin they are scraped with a knife. The substance is then roiled into a mass, in which state'it is called ladanum or labdanum.
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Erosion Control, Reclamator

Name: Sage Rose
Notes: dislikes pruning or root disturbance. It grows very quickly after a fire.
Ecological Function: Domestic Animal Forage, Groundcover, Hedge, Insectory

Name: Prostrate Rosemary
Notes: Indigenous to calcareous rock outcroppings in southern Spain and northern Africa, Prostrate Rosemary performs best in sunny, protected locations where it can cascade over banks and walls, and also does well in rock gardens and in pots. The small lavender flowers attract bees and butterflies, and the fragrant foliage is not favored by deer.

Name: Blue Mountain Sage
Notes: New species. Indigenous to South Africa. Salvia stenophylla Burch. ex Benth. (Lamiaceae) is a perennial aromatic herb, which is widespread in the high altitude areas of the central and eastern parts of South Africa. It is closely related to Salvia runcinata L. f. and Salvia repens Burch. ex Benth. with which it forms a species complex. Taxonomically, distinction between the three taxa is problematic. To distinguish between S. runcinata, S. repens and S. stenophylla the latter has almost smooth stems and sometimes undivided leaves.
Human Use/Crop: Aromatics/Fragrance, Essential Oil, Insect Repellent, Insect Repellent, Medicine, Medicine, Medicine

Name: Cleveland Sage
Notes: Requires soils with good drainage. Best in full sun. Also called chaparral sage and blue sage.

Name: Golden Sage (Beach Sage, Dune Sage, Sand Sage)

Name: Wallflower (Gillyflower)
Notes: Erysimum cheiri, commonly known as common wallflower, is a woody-based herbaceous perennial subshrub in the mustard family that is typically cultivated as a biennial. This plant loves sharp soil drainage as exemplified by its ability to grow in little pockets of gritty soil on stone walls as suggested by its common name of wallflower. It is noted for producing clusters (racemes) of fragrant 4-petaled flowers in a showy spring bloom followed by narrow pendant dehiscent seed pods (siliques). Easily grown in average, dry to medium, well-drained soils in full sun to light shade. Best in full sun in cool northern climates, but appreciates some part shade in the heat of the day in hot southern climates. This flower is a biennial, so self-seeding will be necessary for it to remain in the garden. Sow seed in spring for bloom the following year. One form is upright and slender with an umbrella-like crown, while the other form is dense and low-growing with pendulous branches drooping to near the ground. Notes: A low-growing (i.e. prostrate, decumbent or ascending) shrub usually growing 0.5-3 m tall, but occasionally reaching up to 5 m in height. It has a very spreading habit and individual plants can cover an area 10-15 m wide. Plants growing in more exposed locations that are closer to the sea (e.g. on foredunes) tend to be more low-growing than those found further from the sea (e.g. on hinddunes). Native to the coastal districts of much of eastern and southern Australia (i.e. south-eastern Queensland, eastern New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and south-eastern South Australia). In South Australia it occurs naturally in coastal districts from the southern parts of the Eyre Peninsula eastwards. In Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania it is widespread and found in all coastal districts of these states. Name: Knife-Leaf Wattle (Dogtooth Wattle)
Notes: Acacia cultriformis is a large shrub or small tree growing slowly to 10-20 feet tall and wide. Acacia cultriformis goes by a variety of common names, Knifeleaf Wattle, Knife Wattle and Dogtooth Wattle. Acacia cultriformis has silver white foliage. Acacia cultriformis blooms with a cloud of yellow flowers at the branch tips in the early to mid Spring. Acacia cultriformis will drop branches if they are pruned to excess, just leaving stubs. Acacia cultriformis is drought tolerant and will suffer if given excess water. Acacia cultriformis is winter hardy into the mid teens° F. If left to its own devices Acacia cultriformis is an easy and spectacular addition to the landscape. Propagation is relatively easy by normal seed raising methods following pretreatment by soaking in boiling water or by scarification. Cuttings may be successful but this method is not often used. Propagation of the prostrate form would need to be carried out from cuttings in order to retain the prostrate habit.

Name: Canada Yew (Ground Hemlock)
Notes: Canada Yew is a conifer found in swampy areas, ravines, stream banks and lakeshores in Canada and the U.S.A. It ranges in from Manitoba, Minnesota and Iowa eastward to the coast and south as far as Tennessee and North Carolina. In NC it is found in the mountains. They grow in part shade to shade in moist, cool soil in rich woods, hardwood and conifer forests, swamps, ravines and banks. The stems that touch the ground will root and colonies can be formed. It rarely grows over 5 feet tall. Requires winter shade or dependable winter snow cover. Hardiest of the yews; hardiness south of zone 4 is unknown. Fruit is a cup-shaped, berry-like cone called an aril, up to 3/8 inch long, maturing to bright red, open at the top exposing the single seed in mid to late summer. Canada yew commonly reproduces by layering, forming a continuous population of genetically identical plants. Considered least desirable for landscape purposes.
